headline: China Holds Fire After Trade Talks Fail to Find Deal
summary: China held back from immediate retaliation for higher U.S. tariffs, unlike in past rounds, taking time to weigh its options amid uncertainty over how the Chinese economy would weather a full-bore trade conflict.

headline: Volatility in Stocks Could Unravel Bets on Calm Markets
summary: Recent swings in the stock market are threatening to unravel multibillion-dollar bets that rely on calm markets, potentially adding to investors’ jitters over the past week.

headline: For Investors, a Balanced Diet Beats Food Fads
summary: Beyond Meat’s first week as a listed company shows how famished investors are for healthy-eating options. Judging by the performance of earlier food fads, though, some moderation is needed.

headline: Cuba Plans to Ration Sales of Basic Food Items
summary: Cuba will ration sales of basic goods, officials said, as tighter U.S. sanctions and the economic implosion of key ally Venezuela puts further pressure on the Communist regime to import food staples.

headline: Father of Presidential Candidate  Gillibrand Once Worked for Trump
summary: In an only-in-New York twist, the father of U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand of New York once did lobbying work for Donald Trump, who she is trying to unseat as president.

headline: Pakistan and IMF Reach Loan Deal
summary: The International Monetary Fund has agreed to lend Pakistan $6 billion to bail it out of a balance-of-payments crisis, ending months of negotiations amid a slumping economy.

headline: Citigroup Bets Big on Digital Banking
summary: Executives at Citigroup are convinced that many U.S. consumers are finally ready to leave the branch behind and fully embrace digital banking.

headline: Bristow Group Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Helicopter transportation services company Bristow Group filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after reaching a deal with senior bondholders on a plan to slash its debt load.

headline: ‘Pikachu’ Has Strong Opening but Can’t Defeat ‘Avengers’
summary: Hollywood’s first serious attempt to unseat “Avengers: Endgame” atop the box office made a valiant effort over the weekend, but the superhero sequel still kept the No. 1 spot with a third-week haul of $63.1 million.

headline: Do Charter Schools Replicate?
summary: Yes, a new study says. Time to take artificial caps off their success.

headline: Tax Revenue Keeps Rising
summary: The federal deficit is increasing, and the reason is spending.

headline: This New Democratic Plan Would Ban Private Medicine
summary: Medicare for America isn’t ‘moderate.’ It goes further than Bernie Sanders.

headline: Warren H. Phillips
summary: The former Journal publisher was always a newsman at heart.

headline: How to Liberate Venezuela
summary: The free world needs to squeeze the power behind Caracas’s police state: Cuba.

headline: The Federal Reserve Is Flying Blind on Inflation
summary: Even Alan Greenspan, erstwhile maestro, now acknowledges ‘bias in the statistics.’

headline: John Lukacs Left His Mark on History
summary: The Hungarian exile deflated communism and other horrors of the 20th century.

headline: ‘Overrun’ Review: Too Many Fish to Fry
summary: Asian carp were brought to America to address a number of environmental problems. Now their oversized population threatens natural habitats.

headline: America’s Abusive Trade Practices
summary: China has legitimate grievances, too. The WTO often looks askance at U.S. antidumping tariffs.

headline: Warren Phillips Built a Powerhouse of News
summary: In his 44-year career at the Journal, the paper’s circulation rose from 100,000 to two million.

headline: NotableQuotable: Kevin Warsh on Federal Reserve Independence
summary: ‘If the Fed becomes a general purpose agency of economic policy, it will lose its special monetary prerogatives.’

headline: Economy Week Ahead: Retail Sales, Industrial Production Data
summary: In the week ahead, Germany releases growth figures, while China publishes industrial-production data. In the U.S., agencies will release numbers on retail sales, industrial production and consumer sentiment.

headline: In a Reversal, U.S. to Host Hungarian Prime Minister
summary: Viktor Orban’s visit with President Trump at the White House on Monday comes as the administration worries that the Central European nation is slipping away from Washington’s orbit.

headline: Flash Floods Hit New Orleans and Houston
summary: Heavy rains flooded streets in and around New Orleans, with a flash flood warning issued early Sunday morning before water started receding in some places, the city said.

headline: China Invites U.S. Officials to Continue Trade Negotiations
summary: China has invited U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin to Beijing to continue trade negotiations, White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow said.

headline: Manchester City Takes the Premier League Title
summary: Manchester City clinched back-to-back Premier League titles and has now lifted the trophy in four of the past eight seasons. For Liverpool, a 97-point campaign with just one defeat somehow wasn’t enough.

headline: Yemen’s Houthi Rebels Begin Withdrawal From Key Port
summary: Houthi rebels in Yemen withdrew forces Sunday from the country’s most strategic port, the United Nations said, a step toward salvaging a peace deal that hasn’t been implemented since it was brokered by the U.N. in December.

headline: The Legacy of Eugenics Still Echoes in America
summary: Rather than a “renunciation” of eugenics in the 1930s, forced-sterilization laws persisted for 40 more years at some of the best medical institutions.

headline: Price: An Important Ingredient in All Drugs
summary: The government should require drug companies to provide drugs to all individuals without insurance or who haven’t yet met their deductible at the lowest net price they provide to others.

headline: Chamber of Commerce Delivers for Business in Washington
summary: The chamber is leading the transformation of how business gets done in Washington in a way no one else can.

headline: There’s Hope for Nonlawyers in Small-Claims Courts
summary: Small-claims courts work and usually result in a fair and just result, even when one side presents itself without benefit of counsel.

headline: Nasdaq Lawsuit Over Cybersecurity ETF Fees Goes to Trial
summary: Nasdaq’s lawsuit accusing a New Jersey company of stealing more than $1 billion in exchange-traded funds is set to come to trial Monday in New York.

headline: The World Trade Center’s $3.9 Billion Oculus Has Rip in Its Skylight
summary: A rubber seal that runs along the center of the retractable skylight at the Oculus is believed to have ripped during its opening and closing on the 2018 anniversary of the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

headline: Schools Question Whether They Should Keep Teaching Students to Confront Shooters
summary: In case of a shooting situation, U.S. students are being taught to avoid, barricade, hide and, as a last resort, confront. But the recent deaths of two students who confronted shooters are prompting officials to question the last option.

headline: Lockstep Market Swings Worry Investors
summary: Stocks and commodities around the world generally moved in tandem last week, stoking fears that declines could accelerate across riskier assets if the U.S. and China aren’t able to resolve their trade fight.

headline: Some Small Businesses See Big Benefits in Online Financing
summary: Many small businesses pay higher interest rates when borrowing from online lenders. But in return, they get quicker lending decisions and are more likely to get funding and less likely to have to provide collateral.

headline: Rattled by Cyberattacks, Hospitals Push Device Makers to Improve Security
summary: U.S. hospitals are pressing medical-device makers to improve cyber defenses of their internet-connected infusion pumps, biopsy imaging tables and other health-care products as reports of attacks rise.

headline: Cosco Focuses on Pacific International Lines as Takeover Target
summary: China’s Cosco Shipping Holdings is eyeing Singapore’s Pacific International Lines as a potential takeover target as it looks to expand its footprint in developing markets.

headline: When MAXs Fly Again, Will Passengers Get on Board?
summary: Boeing’s 737 MAX could return to service as soon as this summer after the jet’s world-wide grounding in March. Can it win back the confidence of pilots and passengers in time?

headline: Trump Backed Libyan Warlord After Saudi Arabia and Egypt Lobbied Him
summary: Saudi Arabia and Egypt successfully lobbied President Trump to reverse U.S. policy in Libya and support a rogue general leading an offensive on a government in Tripoli backed by the U.N., according to a senior U.S. administration official and two Saudi officials.

headline: Bipartisan Embrace of Trump’s China Trade Dispute Faces Test as Tariffs Rise
summary: President Trump has enjoyed rare bipartisan cheering for his brass-knuckle trade fight with Beijing, but that support will now be tested as U.S. businesses and consumers shoulder higher tariffs.

headline: Mueller’s Restrained Approach May Clash With Democrats’ Agenda
summary: Robert Mueller’s reluctance to be in the political arena runs headlong into Democrats’ desire that he explain the decisions he made as special counsel.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Is Ending. What’s the Outlook for the Trebuchet Industry?
summary: The blockbuster TV series, shot in Northern Ireland, spawned a host of moneymaking opportunities for local blacksmiths, taxidermists, jewelers, hotels and restaurants; ‘We will never see its like again.’

headline: Uber and Lyft Confront High Driver Turnover
summary: Uber and Lyft are banking on a future where ever-more riders rely on ride-hailing. But that future assumes the companies will be able to accomplish something pretty difficult—finding enough drivers.

headline: A New-Look TV Industry Descends on Madison Avenue
summary: Advertisers will get their first look this week at what the broadcast networks have cooked up for the fall TV season. The major networks all have fresh faces calling the shots on their programming after a year of big change in the industry.

headline: The Best Truly Wireless Headphones—Besides AirPods
summary: Truly wireless headphones are a must-have—not just for music, but also for Siri, Google Assistant, podcasts, audiobooks, talking to your friends and watching Instagram Stories—and Apple AirPods are far from the only option.

headline: Foiled North Korean Escape Ignites Human-Rights Debate
summary: China’s detention of a 9-year-old girl and six other North Koreans who tried to escape their country has triggered a public outcry that South Korea’s president, while pursuing peace talks, must confront Pyongyang about rights abuses.

headline: Next Generation Acela Rail Cars Taking Shape in N.Y. Factory
summary: The first of 28 new Amtrak Acela train sets are being built in upstate New York, part of a $2 billion fleet of high-speed trains due to begin running from Washington, D.C., to Boston two years from now.

headline: Small Businesses Are Squeezed by Tight Labor Market
summary: Job growth at the smallest businesses has fallen to the lowest levels in nearly eight years as tiny companies struggle to attract and retain workers in the tightest U.S. job market in half a century.

headline: Buffett and Bezos Miss Out on Long-Term Money
summary: The absence of Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway from stock-market indexes for long-term gains reveals the difficulties faced by those who want a simple way to invest for a distant horizon.
